Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned the fundamentals of linear algebra and multivariable calculus in this class. I learned how to best balance my in and out of class work to maximize my efficiency in this class.
This class was a good overview of topics in multi-variable calculus and linear algebra.
You will learn basic linear algebra and calculus 3 up to Lagrange multipliers.
Basic linear algebra and multivariable calculus.
I learned the material for sure but I had to self teach and did not find the in class lectures very useful

This course taught me various calculus and linear algebra techniques that will be helpful for economics. I learned how to solve multivariable problems as well as how to work with matrices, vectors, and min/maximization problems.
Derivatives
basic multi, basic lin al
The course gave me an overview of basics of linear algebra and multivariable calculus with the focus on derivatives.
By taking this course, I developed a foundational understanding of how to solve systems of equations via matrices and how to differentiate functions with multiple variables.
I learned linear algebra and multivariable calculus (but only the basics of each).
Basic linear algebra and basic multi variable Calc
I learned the fundamentals of linear algebra and multivariable differential calculus, and about the crossroads between the two fields.
I developed an understanding of multivariable calculus and linear algebra.

You will learn linear algebra and multivariable calc fundamentals, stuff with with matrices and vectors. I think conic sections got some people with the 3d graphs/contours stuff and the partial derivative stuff itself wasn't hard except if you made mistakes with the log. Near the end, it got a little harder with Lagrange multipliers but the work is very manageable.
I developed robust skills in the basics of Linear algebra and multi-variable calculus. Very straight forward class.

The class is clearly designed to teach the fundamentals of linear algebra and multivariable calculus to economics and other socials science major students. As a result, the content was not too difficult but still supplied us with important basics that will be useful in the future. A lot of class time was devoted to working example problems, which was good for preparing for quizzes. However, it would have perhaps been helpful to spend more time understanding concepts and the derivation of equations and methods.

The weekly quizzes really help you not get too behind in the course. However, I did not like how the material we were learning in class was the material on a quiz two weeks later. This was not really an issue at the beginning of the school year, but as the course dragged on, the quiz and the material learned seemed to drift further apart.

The course is fairly well-structured. The first half of the class is linear algebra, which is fairly straightforward, and the second half of the class is Calc 3, which is much faster paced and complex.
The class moves at a pretty solid rate and, on the whole, makes sense
Some of the final and midterm questions were not accurate to what we had learned and been tested on during quizzes

The biggest strength of this course is its structure - the weekly homeworks and quizzes ensure that students stay on top of the material and practice it enough to learn it. The course is also very straightforward, in that the material assigned for the homework matches what is on the quizzes which matches what is on the exams. I found that this made the course very fair, and made studying relatively straightforward. Prof. Rosenthal is also generous enough to hold weekly review sessions to ensure students can ask questions and clear up difficulties.
Professor is bad
good structure for doing well in class but was difficult to truly understand reasoning/ math behind why to do things (as opposed to how to do things)
I think that the course was overall great in teaching the material but could improve through better organization.

Strengths: material isnt hard, class is small and good for learning/asking, weekly review sessions and quiz. 
weakness: a bit confusing with quiz of the week being about a topic that werent covering that week.

The course is structured very very well. No psets, just quizzes every week. The weakness is the Professor. He is a smart guy but does not know how to teach concepts. Or explain anything. When someone asks a question he kind of just puts it off. But the textbooks are helpful so thats how youll learn. And he takes off points for the silliest things. Ugh.
Professor Rosenthal has structured classes (in my view) in a perfect way. The schedule of quizzes and review sessions was extremely beneficial.
This course provides a very cursory overlook into linear algebra and multivariable calculus. The course does not make any direct reference to applications within the social sciences.

Strengths:
-the review sessions on Wednesdays Prof Rosenthal holds are technically optional, but most people agree that it was the most helpful class each week. You basically go over the questions he selects from the homework as important the day before the weekly quizzes. They are almost like class, and I think almost everybody came because they were so helpful
-professor is a fun guy, I think he liked our class, was friendly in a teasing way

Weaknesses
-sometimes in lesson I felt like the material could have been explained more clearly; oftentimes a concept wasn't hard but the way he explained it was a little confusing, but you have the textbook if you really can't understand
-the textbook is overpriced for this class, and make sure you get the right one because you need two (one linear algebra, one multivariable) and a bunch of people bought the wrong edition at the beginning of the year and it was a hassle to return it once they realized, halfway into the class
Very, very straightforward class where the quiz material is covered by our weekly homeworks. I liked how it was much easier than 120 or 223 but you get the basics for both.

I would recommend this course to students interested in social science who are not great fans of difficult math. I found this class useful in learning the essentials of linear and multivariable, and now feel that I will have the necessary fundamental knowledge for future economics courses. However, if students are searching for in-depth and super-challenging math, I would suggest another class.

I took this class because I was hoping it would be an easier version of 120. It was, and if you are trying to fulfill a math requirement for a major like Econ, then I think this is a good choice. However, if you are trying to be an Econ/Math major or another major that requires more math, you may want to take 120 and then 222 (or another linear algebra course).

I would not recommend this course to most students. The material is not incredibly difficult, but for an Econ major, the class doesnt focus on Econ-relevant topics until the very end the term. The course does have some advantages in its structure because there are weekly quizzes and review sessions.
I would if you're interested in Econ/some other social science. Or if you enjoyed calc BC in high school and want to learn more, but don't want to take it all the way up to 120.

Maybe if you're willing to put extra effort in to learning the material on your own time and have a strong command of the material so you can handle questions on the midterms/final that were not reviewed during the quizzes

I'd recommend this course to a student who needs calculus for their economics (or other) degree, but doesn't feel comfortable taking a more advanced multivariable class. This course would probably not be suitable for a math or engineering major, as it does not cover all the material they need.
Would not recommend with the professor
Yes ,good basic foundation
Yes! If you major on economics, it is a useful course.
I would recommend this course because it introduces to students important topics in both linear algebra and multivariable calculus without overwhelming them in terms of the level of difficulty.
Yes! take it.
It is a good ending math for Econ majors. Good overview of concepts. But thats if you want to deal with the weaknesses of the professors teaching.
It is a good course for gaining the fundamental skills needed for mathematics in economics. However, the math often felt a bit simplistic, which may not be satisfying for those seeking a challenge.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are not seeking to take any further math classes.

It says it's for econ majors, and I think basically everybody in the class wanted to do econ so if that's not the major you want to take, I wouldn't recommend this course. But it was pretty straightforward material, the weekly quizzes kept you on track, and the pace was pretty slow. The only weird thing was that he would teach material that would then be quizzed the week after, so the material was always a week ahead/ quizzes were always a week behind.
Only if you hate math and need the econ credit.
